summary: This is a federal court opinion and order by Judge Lorna G. Schofield regarding a plaintiff's motion to dismiss her civil lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell and the executors of Jeffrey Epstein's estate with prejudice. The dismissal is connected to the plaintiff's participation in and acceptance of an offer from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program. The order grants the dismissal with modified conditions, rejecting Maxwell's request for an unredacted copy of the release but striking language about each party bearing its own costs.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.role: Co-Executor of the Estate of Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Named defendant in his official capacity as an executor of Epstein's estate. He and Richard D. Kahn are referred to as the 'Co-Executors' who established the victims' compensation program.

persons.name: Richard D. Kahn
persons.role: Co-Executor of the Estate of Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: Named defendant in his official capacity as an executor of Epstein's estate, alongside Darren K. Indyke.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Defendant in the civil lawsuit who opposed the plaintiff's motion to dismiss. She objected to the proposed dismissal order, arguing she would be prejudiced without an unredacted release and the ability to seek costs.

persons.name: Jeffrey Edward Epstein
persons.context: The deceased individual whose estate is being administered by Indyke and Kahn. The plaintiff's claims stem from alleged sexual abuse by Epstein and Maxwell.

persons.name: Lorna G. Schofield
persons.context: The judge authoring the opinion and order, deciding the motion for voluntary dismissal with prejudice.

persons.name: Judge Freeman
persons.context: Previously stayed the case based on the understanding the plaintiff wished to participate in the victims' compensation program.

connections.description: Served together as co-executors of Jeffrey Epstein's estate.
Indyke acted as an executor for Epstein's estate after his death.
Kahn acted as an executor for Epstein's estate after his death.
The plaintiff's lawsuit alleges claims of battery, false imprisonment, and emotional distress stemming from the alleged sexual abuse by both Epstein and Maxwell.
Co-defendants in the civil lawsuit, with Indyke being sued in his official capacity as estate executor.
Co-defendants in the civil lawsuit, with Kahn being sued in his official capacity as estate executor.

events.title: Civil Complaint Filed
events.description: Plaintiff filed a Complaint against Ghislaine Maxwell and the co-executors of Epstein's estate, alleging battery, false imprisonment, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.

events.title: Victims' Compensation Program Established
events.description: The Superior Court of the U.S. Virgin Islands granted the co-executors' motion to establish the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

events.title: Case Stayed
events.description: Judge Freeman stayed the civil case based on the understanding the plaintiff wished to participate in the compensation program.

events.title: Plaintiff Submits Claim
events.description: Plaintiff submitted a claim to the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

events.title: Plaintiff Accepts Compensation Offer
events.description: Plaintiff received and accepted an offer of compensation from the program, executing a General Release in exchange.

events.title: Motion to Dismiss Filed
events.description: Plaintiff filed a motion to dismiss the civil action with prejudice.

events.title: Court Issues Dismissal Order
events.description: Judge Lorna G. Schofield issued an opinion and order granting the motion to dismiss with prejudice, subject to modification and plaintiff's consent.

locations: United States District Court Southern District of New York
Superior Court of the United States Virgin Islands
keyFacts: A plaintiff moved to dismiss her civil lawsuit with prejudice after accepting a compensation offer from the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program, which required dismissal of existing lawsuits.

Ghislaine Maxwell opposed the dismissal unless she received an unredacted copy of the plaintiff's release (showing the compensation amount) and unless language about each party bearing its own costs was removed.
The court rejected Maxwell's request for the unredacted release, stating she was not entitled to information from this case for use in public opinion or her separate criminal trial.
The court agreed to strike the language about costs from the dismissal order, allowing Maxwell to potentially seek costs later, as the issue was not ripe for adjudication at dismissal.
The plaintiff's claims alleged battery, false imprisonment, and emotional distress stemming from the alleged sexual abuse by Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell.
